title: The Sustainability of Open Education at Community Colleges
segmentation: Now the Maricopa Community Colleges are located in Arizona, in the United States, we are arguably the largest Community College in the district in the nation.
We have over 250,000 students.
So we have a great number of students.

One of the things I'd like to share with you is I was very excited when we landed here just a week ago and we saw fields of dandy Lions and dandy Lions are almost everywhere, and some people view the dandelion as a weed while others view the dandelion as a flower publishers view.
Oh, we are more as a weed, but our students see a beautiful brilliant flower in the opportunity to have great resources.
That they can access on day one and not have to spend a lot of money on.
And I remember being a child and when the dandelions would turn to silveran you could close your eyes and make A wish.
Ann.
I think a lot of our students are making wishes for more O ER for affordable textbooks.
And I'd like to thank will West from Tacoma Community College for the idea of this idea of the dandelions.
Now at the Maricopa Community, Colleges, Ovr didn't just suddenly miraculously appear everywhere as started as pockets of innovations.
I little bits of ideas people using reusable learning objects and open educational resources in their classes.
And starting with it, it wasn't an organized effort.
It was faculty finding a need and finding good resources that they could use an adapt and.
As those projects grew, we ended up having more and more.
So we are projects sprouting out, and as those ideas sprouted, we started.
You develop roots and this is really important in terms of the sustainability of open educational resources at the Maricopa Community colleges.
Because yes, we had those grassroots of our faculty wanting to use open educational resources and our students starting to see the value.

But what happened was our roots cut deeper because our Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost, the leader of the community, come one of the leaders of the Community College District and our governing board.
So value in open educational resources and they supported what we were doing and they wanted us to move in a strategic direction with our open educational resources.
So we started developing these routes and we grew more routes.
We developed us a steering team and we asked people to serve on the steering team and the response was like weeds.
We had so many people wanting to join us.
We had two college presidents, our Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost.
Faculty librarians IT professionals all wanting to be a part of this ovr movement at the Maricopa Community Colleges.
And we started tending to these dandelions to these open educational resources.
We started offering workshops to educate our faculty.
We started offering grant programs so faculty could develop open educational resources.
They could take the time to find, adapt, Remix, create an, re, distribute their open educational resources.
And it became a collaborative project.
We have 10 community colleges in our district and often we don't play well together.
Sometimes we don't want to work together, we just want to do our own thing.

But this became a collaborative project where we were able to spread O ER and we were able to get faculty from multiple colleges to work together and develop and work with materials so that they could say, hey, we want to develop first year composition.
Why don't we get a couple faculty from different colleges to work together to do this?

And this began to evolve, so it's not just using open educational resources, but we're just starting now to look at the idea of editing cycles quality review using different materials to make sure that the quality is there that we need for our students to learn so that our curriculum is aligned and making sure that the open educational resources don't get stagnant that they're staying true.
And what I think is the most exciting thing about the open educational resources movement and what we have surely benefited from an from all the community colleges.
Is this idea of sharing across institutions.
And so we had so many people are helping us.
So we had the CCC.
Oh, we are helping us.
We worked with Lumen and Kaleidoscope and other community colleges.
There were all these different projects out there, one Community College, Tidewater Community College.
Created an entire degree program that is open educational resources where their students could do their whole schooling with all open educational resources.
So we worked together and we borrowed, which is the whole idea of ovr.
And then we started sharing out with the world.
So we're here.
Today we gave a presentation yesterday.
We do workshops at some of our sister community colleges.
We've gone to other colleges to share what we're doing, and so it's spreading like weeds in a really good way.
And we are being now these open educational resources.
These dandy Lions that my mother would have wanted to get rid of in our garden.
They are being showcased in shared.

There were showcasing them in so many different ways and we have high quality peer reviewed, open educational resources being offered through the Open Stacks Project an we're being able to really show what we're doing in borrowing from people all over the world and showcasing that.
And we're providing sustenance.
Our model has changed our students search through the schedules to find the courses that open that offer, either free or open materials we have.
I have a colleague who had a student say I'm not taking any courses this summer because there's no are available.
That's transformative.

And here in Slovenia I did some research and I hope this is correct, but it's my understanding that Slovenians celebrate spring with dandy Lions and that it's a sign of spring and not only are dandelions and are open educational resources doing so many different things that they are, but they are providing the sustenance of the education for our students, and I think that's what's really transformative.
And the remarkable about what we're doing at the community colleges at Maricopa.
And what we're all doing together, so I'm going to turn this over to Una daily.
